abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            Copperbelt Environment Project (CEP) that tackled the lead
            and uranium danger in Zambia. In 1995, the government sold
            the mines to private investors. Although privatization
            brought many benefits to the economy, the new mine owners
            did not want to take care of the environmental liabilities
            left over by previous mines’ owners. In 2003, fifty thousand
            residents of Kabwe’s population were affected by high lead
            levels in the soil, due to naturally occurring
            mineralization as well as the impact of the smelting and
            mining operations. Although mining has been the single
            greatest contributor to economic growth in Zambia, it has
            also had significant adverse effects on the environment. Its
            effect on the environment had been largely ignored, thus
            leaving a trail of uranium, lead and other base metals whose
            by-products were not properly disposed of and administered.
            CEP determined and controlled lead blood levels in affected
            areas. It also helped to strengthen the institutional
            capacity of delegated authorizing agencies to improve future
            compliance of the mining sector with environmental and
            social regulations. The International Development
            Association (IDA) financed environmental project helped to
            clean up lead and uranium tailings from mines in Zambia and
            enabled the residents of Kabwe live in safety.
